questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as_____.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the therapist has mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as counter-transference.

Counter-transference is the positive and negative feelings/emotions expressed by healthcare professionals towards their patients. It is the process of the physician unconsciously displacing onto the patient patterns of behaviors or emotional reactions as if he/she were a significant figure from earlier in the physician's life. Psychiatrists should be alert to signs of countertransference issues like missed appointments by the psychiatrist, boredom, or sleepiness during a session. Supervision and personal therapy can help the psychiatrist recognize and deal with these issues. 

Transference is the positive and negative feelings expressed by the patients towards the healthcare professional. It is the process of the patient unconsciously displacing onto individuals patterns of behavior and emotional reactions that originated with significant figures from the past (generally in childhood). This displacement is onto the psychiatrist in a clinical scenario, who is a parent surrogate. The patient may be angry, hostile, demanding, or obedient to an extreme degree because of former relationships and patterns of behaviors. Failure to recognize this can make the psychiatrist react to the patient's behavior like a personal attack.

These are not defense mechanisms but are commonly encountered during clinical practice or while giving psychotherapy. In an interview, transference and counter-transference are very significant expressions of unconscious processes.

Option C: Dissociation is an immature defense mechanism. In this, involuntary splitting/suppression of mental functions occurs from the rest of the personality in a way that allows the expression of forbidden unconscious impulses without having a sense of responsibility for actions.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D - Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of a heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

Note: Tremulousness is the first alcohol withdrawal symptom.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated the steps of handwashing to her students. Students also performed the same activity later at school and at home. What is the type of learning in this case?
questions.solution:
The type of learning seen in this case is psychomotor learning.

The psychomotor domain includes learning by observation, physical movements, and the usage of motor skill areas of the brain. The development of these skills requires practice, depending upon the complexity of the task. It is measured based on speed, precision, distance, and procedures in execution.

The three domains in learning are the cognitive, psychomotor, and affective domains. They are described as follows.

Cognitive learning includes the domain of knowledge. Bloom's taxonomy described six levels of cognitive skills. This was revised to include types of knowledge and cognitive processes. The cognitive processes include remembering, understanding, applying, analyzing, evaluating, and creating. Eg. Solving multiple-choice questions in the NEET PG entrance exam involves the usage of the cognitive domain. 

Psychomotor learning includes the domain of skills. It includes imitation, manipulation, precision, articulation, and naturalization. Eg. Learning how to insert an IV cannula by observing the residents and nurses during the internship involves the usage of the psychomotor domain.

Affective learning includes the domain of attitude and values. It includes receiving, responding, valuing, organizing, and characterization by value. Eg. Communicating with patients with empathy, responding to their concerns, and interacting with the relatives of patients involves the usage of the affective domain.

Integration of all these three methods in teaching and learning methodology leads to a better understanding of the subject.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Derailment is a formal thought disorder.

It is a breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of being goal-oriented. It is generally identified in schizophrenic patients as a generalized loosening of associations.

For example, a person with derailment thought disorder might jump from talking about rabbits to the hair on their head to your sweater. They talk in chains of semi-related ideas. Their communication style has a generalized loosening of associations. Their ideas often fall further and further from the topic. 

Formal thought disorders are:

  • Circumstantiality is the overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impedes the sense of getting to the point.
  • Clang association is an association of thoughts with the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming).
  • Derailment is the breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
  • Flight of ideas is a succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea, through rapid, pressured speech.
  • Neologism is the invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.
  • Perseveration is the repetition of out-of-context words, phrases, or ideas.
  • Tangentiality is responding to a question, that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question. 
  • Thought blocking is a sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas.

Other options:

Option A - An obsession is a recurrent and intrusive thought, feeling, idea, or sensation.

Option C - A delusion is defined as a false belief based on incorrect inference about external reality that firmly sustains despite evidence to the contrary.

Option D - Thought insertion is a type of delusion where the patient believes that thoughts are not his/her own and have been inserted into his/her mind.

Controversial: The classification of OCD as a certain form of thought is debatable based on the resource. Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th Edition) lists it under disorders of content of thought, whilst Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (4th Edition) mentions it under disorders of possession of thought.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudohallucination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, history of overfamiliarity, elevated mood, flight of ideas, and increased sexual desire are suggestive of mania.

The diagnostic criteria for mania are:

A. Distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, and abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting at least 1 week.

B. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy/activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms are present to a significant degree:

1. Increased self-esteem or grandiosity

2. Decreased need for sleep

3. More talkative than usual or a pressure to keep talking

4. Flight of ideas

5. Distractibility

6. Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation

7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions)

C. The mood disturbance is severe enough to cause marked social or occupational impairment or to necessitate hospitalization.

D. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or to another medical condition.


Other options: 

Option B - Hypomania is a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated/irritable mood, abnormally and persistently increased activity/energy, lasting for at least 4 days. It is similar to a manic episode but it is not severe enough to cause impairment in social or occupational functioning. No psychotic features are present.

Option C - Cyclothymia is a mild, chronic mood disorder with numerous depressive and hypomanic episodes over the course of at least 2 years.

Option D - Schizomania is an old term in DSM III, used to describe schizophrenic and manic symptomatology occurring in one episode, classified under schizoaffective disorder. Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by active phase symptoms of schizophrenia, like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized behavior, or negative symptoms. Additionally, there is a presence of manic/depressive syndrome that is not brief relative to the duration of the psychosis. The delusions or hallucinations are present for at least 2 weeks without coexisting mood symptoms.

 

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)
